Pours a golden with a slight haze and a light, foamy white head.  Light, sweet floral aroma. Taste is refreshing, light, with a touch of citrus tang.  Subtle resemblance to their 312 brand.  Very easy on the palate.  Summertime doesn’t have distinctive features that would separate it from other Kolsh inspired brews, yet it’s still refreshing and easy to throw down a few.  Solid Goose outing

Botle. Pours a yellow, cloudy juice with a small white head. Aroma is refreshingly citrusy, hoppy, fruity, little caramel maltiness in the background. Taste is crisp, citrusy hoppy, fruity, lime, some maltiness in the middle, grapefruit end. Palate is light and carbonated, very refreshing. Gladly would drink a whole bunch of these in a row.

the beers pours a dright, clear, fizzy pee colored gold with a white head. Has no lacing.

It doesn’t smell like anything and tastes the same.

It tastes like water, utterly horrible. It looks like a bud light and tastes like natty light.
355 ml bottle served in a wine-tasting glass. 3 mm white head, light yellow body. Nose: Banana foam, yeast, wheat, ripe banana. Taste: Banana foam, wheat, wine-gum. Very fresh, high drinkability.

355ml bottle. It pours an orangey-golden colour and it is slightly hazy, though it eventually almost becomes translucent.A nice sized head which mostly disappears but there s still enough remaining to present a good appearance. There s a nice refershing level of carbonation. The taste is nutty and malty, quite muesli-like. The structure and texture is quite substantial for this kind of beer and it is refreshing on the end as expected. Nice summer beer!
Does not resemble German versions, it is pretty flat. They didn’t even spell it right so i guess it isn’t a Koelsh, but a Kolsh which would be an American butchery of a Koelsch.
Clear golden with a white head. Aroma is sweet, light malty and light hoppy - citrus. Flavor is medium sweet and light bitter. Sweet finish. A bit light bodied. Boring. 150910
Bottle. Pours golden with a medium white head. The aroma is malt, fruit and some fruity hops. The flavour is citrus, fruit and caramel. Refreshing.
12 oz. bottle to pilsner glass.  Pours golden with a thin white head.  Nice floral and slight citrus.  Mild bitter finish.  Made a nice session beer.

12 ounce bottle from State Line Liquors. Pours a hazy orange color with minute floating particles. Medium creamy tan head. Good head retention and lacing. Aroma of bread, grain, caramel, faint spice. The taste is caramel, grainy malts and some toastiness. Medium bodied.

I drank this a lot last summer because we had it at work and also I love kolsch. Can’t say this is even close to being the best kolsch but it is still extremely refreshing and way better that 312. So if im in Chicago, and its 90 degrees our with 30% humidity, I’ll gladly grab one of these are drink it. Very crisp and dry. Slightly everything....meaning it has taste and depth but very slightly.

Aroma is grains, yeast and a hint of hops.  The flavor is mildly sweet malts and a hint of hops in the finish.  The difference between the old version of this with the twist tops and the traditional pry-off way is it now definitely helps with the flavor.
Bottle. Poured golden colour with thin white head. Aroma is malty, fruity and freash. Flavour is sweet, grassy and fruity.

Biggish white head. Hazy opaque pale yellow body with light carbonation. Light wheaty citric spicy aroma with oily notes. Dryish-sweet fruity orangey wheaty taste with papery mealy notes. Mid-bodied. Chalky, peppery mouthfeel. Dryish mealy herbal aftertaste. Not bad, but very anonymous. (0.355l bottle, Fish & Beer, Copenhagen.)

Slightly less fruity than what the name might suggest. Aroma lacks intensity. Could easily be made more attractive by evolving the Kölsch genre. But then again, maybe kölsch just isn’t the favourite genre of most beer geekoes.

Bottled on March 5, 2009

A: Pours a very light yellow-grain color with about two fingers worth of head and plenty of carbonation. The bubbles are nice to watch through the transparent beer--wish I’d poured this one into my Sam Adams perfect pint. Excellent lacing.

S: Sweet grains. Some hints of hoppy citrus.

T: Much like the smell, the initial taste is sweet grains, with some light fruits in there as well. Ever-so-slightly bitter.

M: Very light and crisp. Good amount of carbonation. No alcohol presence.

D: Exceedingly drinkable--this will indeed be a great summertime brew.

Yellow and hazy. Honey and citrus aroma with a little bit of hop. Light beer with some honey and citrus flavour. Paid too much for this though. Also, it is obviously not the best time of the year to have this beer. I wouldn’t mind having a few of these next summer but to have more than one of these at a time is just a bit too expensive as I paid more than 4 euros for this bottle.
Bottle @ Home. Light golden, white head. Light hops, some fruit in the nose. Taste is light hops. grass, floral, some fruit like apples. Light bodied, refreshing, but not really interesting.
Fresh aroma of light citrus, malted sweetness, grains and straw. Flavors of toffee, light caramel, honey, and a hint of grass. Easy to drink, and is what it is.
Pours a cloudy yellow, with a medium white head. Aroma is fruity, grassy, and a bit of lemony zest. Taste was quite sweet, with a nice amout of flavor throughout. Very easy, drinkable beer.
(Draught)  Pours a clear pale yellow with a moderate white head.  Aroma of grass, grain, and light citrus.  Flavor of toasted grain, citrus, and straw.

(bottle) Pours a hazy light yellow with a medium white head that recedes quickly but provides some good lacing.  A really great aroma, plenty of clove, lemon peel, lightly peppery, a hint of vanilla with some floral undertones as well.  Very bright and clean aromatically.  Flavor falls short of the aroma, with some crackery malt in the mid, lemon zest right before the finish, and some dry mineral-like crispness on the finish before the crackery malt appears again upon exhalation.  Mouthfeel is medium, and the spike of carbonation before the finish really assists in lifting the lemon zest flavor up as well.  A really easy drinking and enjoyable beer that would be great in the summer, but is also enjoyable here in the fall.

Bottle. Pours a cloudy dark yellow color with a small, filmy off white head. Nose is grassy, straw, honey, clove. Palate is tickly with a light stickiness and a lightly dirty finish. Flavor is straw, pepper, grass, honey.

(355 ml bottle. Rated @ 18.8.2010.)

Yellow colour with a massive head. Lively CO2 can be seen on the appearance. Light fruitness and floral hops on the nose. Sweet and mildly hoppy taste with a hint of citrus. Light bitter mouthfeel and a dry finish. Refreshing.

Clear bright yellow. White head. Smells like grass, malt, apricot and a hint of
apple juice. taste is sweet and juicy with a bit of wheat flavours. A bit impressed how good it taste despite the low alcohol. best  enjoyed a hot summer day. Very drinkable.
Clean golden colour with white head. Aroma is subtle with slight citrus and malt. Flavour is a little sour and weak body was equally weak.
Poured a medium golden color.  Good carbonation.  Aroma was citrus, and a little spice.  Flavor was floral with a little bit of bitter at the end.   Meh.

This is one of those beers that can’t decide if it is good or not.  Sometimes I have it and dislike it and sometimes it is pretty good.  Right now dislike times are slightly out number like times.  It is light and good for summer but sometimes can have a weird flavor. Serving: Bottle and Tap

On tap, clear golden pour, dry fruity lemon aroma, bitter lemon and grapefruit
rind flavor, bitter dry finish

Hey, I liked it.  Not sure why it’s so lowly rated.  Pale yellow with smallish head.  Grainy aroma.  Flavor was sweet grain but not so much that this still isn’t a refreshing beer for a hot summer day.  Some saazlike hops in the back end.  Not as smooth as I would have wanted, but still quite enjoyable.
Draft at Waterfront Wednesday.  This beer was simple and solid and great for a hot humid summer night, but it is certainly one-dimensional.  Fresh and refreshing nonetheless.

Very pale yellow, almost colourless; hazy.  Many fine bubbles.  Fluffy lasting pure-white head.  Clean aroma - typical German lager, but with more hops and less roasted malt.  Some metallic aftertaste.

Pours a slightly cloudy golden yellow with a thick rich white head.  Aroma is sweet malt and a spiciness brought on by the hops.  Full pale malt taste, some honey-like sweetness and mild hop bitterness.  Very simple, yet well balanced flavorful and thirstquenching.

A serving in Harvard square on tap. The color was a fairly light gold pored to have little head. The aroma was a bit fruit but I got some coriander and mild spice as well. Later on i got a bit of skunky funk so maybe this bar was not serving up to standard. Was a refreshing beer for a warm day and enjoyable. Just a let down since I have had some really complex stuff from GI
Flaske: Lysegul let uklar diset øl med et fint skumhoved. Fin duft af malt og en anelse humle. Let drikkelig men også en tand underhumlet i forhold til hvad jeg havde håbet på. Men bestemt drikbar.

mmm, a perfect light "summertime" brew. A good kolsch that really satisfies. One of those beers that I just can not get cold enough, it is a preference for outdoor activities or any sweaty evening, maybe with a plain chicken breast. sounds good right now, I’ll be right back.

355 ml bottle. Slightly hazy pale golden yellow colour, thin white head. Aroma of citrus fruits, apples, malts and yeast. The flavour is mildly wheaty, citrus-fruity, with a slightly bitter, floral finish. Simple and straightforward, but very refreshing.

Presentation: It was poured from a brown 12oz bottle into a pint glass. There is no mention of abv% but the back label does have a bottled on date of 04/07/10. 

Appearance: Its body has a light yellow gold color with great clarity. On top of the body is a small white creamy head. The head fades fast and makes only a very little slick lacing.

Smell: The aroma has nice sweet bready notes with delicate fruity esters. I get notes of peach, banana and white grape.

Taste/Palate: I get all the same delicate fruitiness and mellow bready sweetness in the flavor as I did in the aroma. This light bodied beer has mild carbonation and a smooth light texture which is quite quaffable.

Notes: This is defiantly a great hot weather offering with enough interest for me to drink it any time of the year.
355 ml bottle. Slightly hazy yellow with medium white head. Flavour is malt, fruit, citrus and dry.

It’s hazy golden with a white, creamy head, and the aroma has notes of malt and fruit. The flavour is moderately sweet with notes of fruit, citrus, malt and the finish is dry. It’s an uncomplicated summer beer, but somewhat boring.

12 oz bottle from Stateline. Not as crisp and clean as it could be for the style. Aroma was all grains with a slight dusty note and no hop prescience. Flavor was allgrains and cereal and better and crisper then the aroma.let on.
tap: thick creamy head. medium body yet creamy and chewy. smooth and light flavor. very sessionable and not offensive. light caramel and bready malts. light pintey hops and some grassy notes.

Avg. creamy white head with nice lacing. Clear yellow body. Mild and sweet apple lemon aroma. Mild sweet apple pear flavor with a pleasant hops bitterness. Low carbonation, long aftertaste. Quite refreshing
pours pale golden rod with a very thin white head and no lacing.  Mildly sweet, citric aroma.  Clean, mildly bitter taste with lemon.  light finish.  refreshing.

Poured from 12 oz bottle.  Aroma is of corn and yeast.  Appearance is clear yellow with not much head.  Taste is the most redeeming quality, nice malt finish, very crisp and refreshing.  A good beer but definitely not a great kolsch.

From bottle. Very light wheat and citrus note, mild sweetness and a bit of yeasty funk. Cloudy pale gold-amber with foamy white lacing head. Medium body with medium-high carbonation. Starts wheaty and mildly sweet with yeast, citrus notes. Mild chalky finish with little bitterness. Nice summer quaff with a touch of honey at the end.

A bottle.  A golden body with a white head.  Aroma had a nice grassy note to it with hints of citrus and wheat.  Flavor was crisp and well balanced, some floral hops and mild wheat malt notes.  A faint hint of citrus.  A nice refreshing beer.

bottled from a sample pack. pours pale golden with a fine white head. smells of orange, corriander, chardonnay grapes, but tastes of grass. more bitter tin like flavor on the palate. i know why they package it with others.

12oz bottle pours golden in color with nice foamy head. Aroma of wheat, straw, grass and honey. Light body tastes much like smells, peppery with floral with slight lingering bitter taste. Decent very drinkable and refreshing.

Left work early to watch wimbeldon and grabbed a pint at Connolley’s not a great tap list put pulled out a couple ratings.  This is a hazy yellow with plenty of citrus and some straw tastes.  very refreshing for start of long weekend
33cl bottle, local store. Poured pale golden bit hazy, with a small white head. Aroma is slightly fruity hoppy. Flavor is bread and wheat, spices, herbs perhaps. Refreshing.

Location: Sampled at the NY Brewfest on Governor’s Island, 6/19/10




Aroma: Nose has some citrus/lemon and yeast to it


Appearance: Clear golden pour into the glass


Flavor: A pretty flavorful beer, some citrus and some sweetness


Palate: This one is rather crisp and enjoyable to drink


Overall Impression: 
A good way to get me started, this was pretty solid stuff.  A nice crisp summer brew.  It has a decent to good flavor, and a nice, crisp mouthfeel to it.

Pours a cloudy golden color with a nice white frothy head.  Has some stong citrus notes and overall is a nice beer.  Very drinkable.

12 oz. bottle
Bottle. Pours gold with a white head. Light grainy aroma with some straw like notes and a light sweetness. The flavor has some grainy pale malty notes and a light floral/earthy hoppiness. Decent.
Cloudy golden color, medium head.  Smooth flavor with not much sensation on the palate. . Better than Blue Moon’s Honey Moon but not as good as Sam Adams Summer Ale for the money.
Very light and refreshing. Aroma has a touch of grainy caramel. Flavor is light and refreshing.

Pours a nice clear golden color. Decent head. Bit of a citrus aroma. Flavor is pretty light,  l title something there. Maybe it’s only carbonation. I’m not too impressed, but it doesn’t taste like water.

Yellow to very light golden in color that was cloudy with average lacing.  Very bright white soapy 1 finger head that settled down to a small ring.  As far as smell, I’m getting the lemon with a hint of some sort of spice;  Also, a bit of wheat or grain that was a nice undertone.  Not too much.  Definitely get the lemon at first with the taste and an underlying citrus flavor.  Little bit of bite but not a whole lot of bitterness at the end.  The mouthfeel was thin, smooth, and crisp.  Mostly watery, however.  This is easily drinkable.  A nice summertime beer obviously, but this was an average beer for me.  Not bad by any means.  I would drink it again if it was offered.
hay, cereal, floral, citrus, banana, bubblegum, golden, hazy, white foam, medium sweetness, lightly bitter, lightly sour, light body, thin feel, soft carbonation,
Sample at Barley’s Smokehouse. Clear yellow pour with a medium white head. Malty nose with lager yeast and a touch of noble hops. Sweet malt flavor with a bitter noble hop finish.

12 oz bottle, hazy golden color, aroma is doughy, malty, a bit of fresh hoppiness, and a bit of sweet fruityness. Taste is sweet with a bit of spice mixed in. Palate was thin and overall a very refreshing beer. Good alternative to a pale lager.
Pours pale gold into a shaker. Bright white head with medium retention recedes to skim surface. Sour caramel aromas. Sour marshmallow upfront turning to a lasting souring malt finish.
Hazy pale orange gold, ring of cap, faint sweet aroma, taste lightly fruity sweetness plus lemon, fairly full, nice simple refresher.
I’ve been on a summertime beer binge, and this definately got me wanting more Kölsch. That’s the best I can say for it.

On tap at McGregors.  Pretty non-descript and not too notable.  Grassy nose, which I’ve smelled plenty of this mowing season.  Taste is similar, plus some grain and copper taste.  Lacing was outstanding, nothing else was.

Bottle.  Pour is very slightly hazy straw color with a medium white head.  Aroma is lightly earthy and floral with hints of grass and a lightly tart component.  Also notes of hay, light malt, and light yeast.  Flavor is lightly malty and yeasty with hints of hay and grass in the finish.  Pretty crisp and clean.  I liked it.
On tap at Wrigleyville.  Light yellow pour with nice white head.  Aroma of lemon and other citrus.  Clean sweet citrus taste. The name is appropriate.
It’s not too bad for a summer beer.  Pretty sweet, malty, tiniest touch of hops.  Very thin bodied, kind of bland overall, finishes with almost no aftertaste.  Very easy to drink lots of em.

I think I prefer this one straight out of the bottle.  It’s a simple beer, goes down good and is a good one to drink several of at a time, which is what I think of when I think of summer.  This one makes me want to by a couple 12 packs and go camping.
Just not Goose’s best effort. Lacks body, lacks flavor, tastes almost homebrewed. Smelly aroma, just not my thing.

Pours very light yellow with a nice white head and lacing.  Smells of faint lemon give into soft hay, grains, and sweet honey.  There’s an initial fruity tartness on the palate that transforms to a nice light grainy flavor.  The finish is rather long with a hoppy bitterness.  I’m delightfully surprised and would have this again.

(bottle - 12 oz) Clear golden pour with a thick white head and lots of carbonation. Very light and fruity aroma with lots of hints of perfume and flowers. Sweet and fruity at the start of the flavor with some dry and grassy notes. Finishes clean and crisp with a light bitter and fruity aftertaste. Really nice and refreshing.

On tap at Goose Island Clybourn.  Pours a lightly hazed gold with a huge white head. Lavender, soapy, bread and toast.  Crisp and grainy, lightly sweet.  Finishes with a light crisp bitterness and a touch of apples and grain.

Very Happy with this seasonal beer, and another great product of Goose Island Brewery in Chi Town!  Pours a cloudy, golden yellow.  Aroma is citrus, orange and lemon.  Taste is citrus and orange, smooth refreshing finish.
On tap with LaCroix at the rattle. Light and sweet kolsh lager.  Great for the style but doesn’t really rub the right way.

Tap at Goose Island Clybourn. Pours clear yellow. Fruity but balanced Kolsch. Sweet but not too sweet. I doubt I would like this in a bottle with the extra carbonation but on tap in the brewpub it was fantastic.

12 oz. bottle from Ludlow Wines.  I like a good Kolsch when it starts getting warm, so it’s nice to see this hit the shelves.  Pours a clear gold with some faint orange tints and a fairly small white head that leaves just a little film atop the beer when it settles.  Aroma of grains, straw, pale malts, hops, dust, and mineral notes.  Flavor follows suit fairly closely, light, with the same notes as above.  Light-bodied, with very sharp, crisp carbonation and a dry finish and no aftertaste.  Nice light beer, choose this over a macro if you’ve got the chance.

From Voldby, DK.
Bottled, 300310.
Yellow with white head. Aroma of fruit with some malt. Flavor of light malt with apricot, orange and citrus
This is a very drinkable beer, quenches your thirst and tastes great. Great summertime ale. Nothing to complain about here overall solid ale. Drink up and enjoy!
12oz bottle. Light cool and refreshing great ale for the summertime. Had many of these wile visiting a friend in Chicago.
Bottle.Clear golden colour with off white head.Aroma is fresh hoppy with light thin body taste of straw and hay mild refreshing with malty smooth finish.

Bottle from Utobeer. Pale golden, hazy, with a smallish head. Hoppy aroma hinting of fruit, hay and herbs. Some fruity acidity, herbal notes, hints of raisins and bread. A perfect summer beer (enjoyed on a cold, early March evening with the snow still covering the city).
Bottle. Golden colour with a white head. Aroma is fruit, malt, grain. Flavour is fruit, malt, grain, hop. Boring beer.

Bottle. A clear, golden beer with a small, white head. Weak nose with grains and fruit. Grassy, grainy straight forward flavor with some flowery notes and a decent bitterness. Dry, but not as dry as it should be, slightly acidic. A really boring beer, but quenching and easy drinkable. 091023

Pours golden with fluffy white head, aroma is light and with some citrus and floral notes.  Taste is light floral hops and lemon, moving into cereal and bread malt that finishes slightly dry.  Not a bad kolsch.

aroma is lightly bready malts with some back graininess. some honey and light lemon.  appearance is lightly hazy gold with excellent carb and thin head, light lacing.  flavor is honey/lemon and good balance of bready malts and floral hops deep in the background. effervescent character adds to refreshment.
Pours cloudy pale yellow with a white head. Aroma har fruity notes, light hop and is light phenolic. Flavour is fresh, light malt, fruity. Light bitter.

Slightly cloydy, light yellow beer with weak but lasting white head. Aroma is mild, some sweet malts, fruity and slightly aromatic; overally positive aroma. Flavour is fresh, malty sweetness, some fruits, mandarin and some drying bitterness in the end. Light nad lot of carbonation but still very smooth and nice to drink. Positively aromatic and enjoyable beer, that was tastefull even now with very cold winter day, maybe hot summer day could be even better for this beer.

Bottle. Creamy white good mostly lasting head. Yellow colour. Moderate malty and hoppy aroma. Some yeasty notes. Moderate bitter nice flavor. Average moderate bitter finish. Some fruity notes. OIly palate. NIce kölch.
On tap at GI Clybourn 7/20/09. Pours clear gold with a funky foot smell.  Mild sweetness of honey and vanilla.  Strange funky aftertaste.

12 fl oz bottle. Pours clear and golden yellow with a small white head. Crisp hoppy aroma, light citrusy note. Mild malty flavoured, light hoppy flavoured - light bitter, mild citrusy and vague peachy smooth. Ends dry, crisp and light citrusy.
Pours light orange with nonexistent head. Aroma is a bit bitter with some malts. Flavor is fruity with some hops in the finish. Quite sour palate. Drinkable.
Bottle at home. Clear golden - white head. Light malty, pilsner malty, grainy, hay, straw, light swetness, nice hoppy, light soapy, light sulphor, grassy. OK.
Golden clear, white head. little bubbly. Nicely hoppy but quite boring. nothing like I expected. Pleasant

12 oz bottle. Slightly cloudy golden color, white head. Slightly hoppy aroma with iron and lemon. Citric hop flavor, malty finish. Light body, medium-light carbonation. Slightly too watery to be good.

From a 12 oz bottle courtesy of Strykzone,  this poured a slightly cloudy golden color with a moderate white head that did not last long and left light lacing.  Nose is mostly of coriander.  Medium body with lots of carbonation. Flavor is mostly of malts with a little fruit.  The finish is dry and slightly bitter,.   A straight-forward and quite drinkable beer.

Dark yellow colored with little white head, lively carbonation. Fruity aroma with some floral hopping, some biting bready note also comes up. Thin to medium bodied. Flavor is more lemony with bitter and slightly floral hops still, aftertaste lasts with some bread and lemon still.
30th June 2008. Comes accross as a soft lager. Unremarkable beer and inoffensive just nothing special at all.
Bottle. Murky golden color, little head. Aroma includes hay, fruits and butter. Flavor is rather refreshing with a citric touch to it. Easy drinking.

Traded bottle. Clear, light gold colour with a small white head and a little lacing. Aroma is buttery with some malt and barn straw. Flavour is bready with a nice mouthfeel. Nothing exciting but fine.
Bottle, 12 fl. oz. Pours a pale yellow beer with a white head. The aroma is weak with fruits and banana. The flavor is likewise weak with banana. The palate is fresh and overall an average beer.
Bottle. Medium head with medium duration. Color is golden. Aroma and taste are malt, hops and citrus. Nice long finish.
Bottled. A golden beer with a thin beige head. The aroma is light with notes of malt and bread. The flavor is sweet with light notes of malt and straw, leading to a lightly bitter finish.

The flavors tasted like a spash or orange juice was added (coriander?) and the beer was pretty chunky.  It was a bit too sweet.  I would not recommend this if you like a traditional Kolsch, but then again, maybe my batch was bad.

Bottle.  Pours a slightly hazy golden color with a thin white head that quickly disipates.  Coriander and yeasty aroma.  Malty and fruity flavor with a mild bitter finish.  Creamy texture with fizzy carbonation.  Nothing fancy, just a smooth, easy drinking brew.

cloudy yelllow, smooth small white head.
malty aroma, sweet corn?.
flavor is sweet, malty, flowery, faint honey.

Botella. Unclear pale yellow colour, medium fairly well alsting white head. Aroma has some fruitiness with wheat and yeast. Fair mouthfeel. Strange wheat and grainy, mildly fruity, bit herby flavour with a bit of lemon and a mild bitterness.
Pale yellow, rather watery looking.  Slightly tart in aroma and taste.  Just enough taste to let you think you are drinking a micro brew.

Pours a clear light yellow/golden color.  Aroma of yeast, lemon and grain.  Very light on flavor.  I can hardly discern a taste.  Perhaps citrus with a slight grain at the end.  Easy drinking, but not much flavor.

Draught at the Ginger Man, NYC on 25th July 2009. Pale, hazy gold with mostly diminishing white foam. Refreshing, lightly hoppy; slight fruits on the nose, all delivered on a fizzy textured mouthfeel with some clinginess on the roof of the mouth.

33 cl bottle, Fargo, ND, USA. Slightly hazy pale yellow colour, foamy head. Bready and citrus aroma, sour lime first sip that spreads through the mouth, almost chalky texture. Very drinkable - someone should turn all the bud-light-lime drinkers on to this.
Tap from Goose Island pub in Wrigleyville. Pours a hazy yellow with minimal head. Light citrus aroma with a light flavor of fruit and malt.
A 35.5cL bottle from local market. Mild nose. Pale head. Pale yellow colour. Mild slightly sour taste with some hints of lemon. Mild hoppiness. Easy to drink. Slightly bitter.

12oz bottle.  FIltered yellow-orange color with a respectable soapy head.  Sweet malt and noble hop aroma.  Pretty underrated, simply because of the style I’d assume.  Maybe a touch more hop bite than most German examples.  Classic, easy drinking beer.  Light creamy yeast balances it out perfectly.  Good stuff.
Golden beer with a decent sized white head. Smell of citrus and yeast. Flavor is malt with some citrus. Decent lacing around the glass. Not bad on a hot day but there are others I would rather have

Bottle @ Vinens Verden, Odense. Pours hazy yellow with a small creamy white head and lacings. Nose is fruity, grassy and floral hops. Very fresh. Taste is dry and crisp. Medium and smooth palate. Easy, tasty and quaffable.

Tap at the brewpub &#40Clybourn location&#41: Golden pour with a consistent white film of head. Fruit snack esters in the aroma with a touch of mild pale grains. Fluffy feel with a simple flavor. Some nondescript grains and fruity esters precede a very mildly hopped &#40hardly notable&#41 finish. Simple & boring, but with no major flaws.
A pretty decent clean Kolsch that goes down nice and easy during the summer...time.

(Bottled) Very hazy yellow with a small, firm head. Lemony, quite fresh and fruity aroma with some grassy hops and hints of acidity. Flavor of pale malt, lime-lemony fruitiness, no bitterness or acidity, but a touch of cardboard. Light to medium body, somewhat refreshing with slightly fizzy carbonation. A reasonable summer beer, but the lack of flavor and only medium freshness makes it less tempting.
Bottle. Pours slight hazy golden coloured with almost no head. Aromas of grain, grass, citrus and green fruit. Refreshing flavour with notes of pale malt, mild grassy hops and fruit. Nice one.

Bottle. High and lasting creamy white head leaving nice lacings. Clear yellow body. Mild and sweet apple lemon aroma. Mild sweet apple pear flavor with a pleasant hops bitterness. Low carbonation, long aftertaste. Quite refreshing
on tap at Giordano’s in Chicago. Refreshing and flavorful with a nice aftertaste
330ml Bottle. Yellow pour with white head. Lots of carbonation. Very light fuity taste. Good summer beer but not much taste.
Draft at GI (Clybourn).  Pours a light yellow color.  Small white head.  Citrus & bready aroma.  Mild fruit flavor.  Crisp.  Very mild carbonation.  Easy drinking.
Poured a pale yellow with a small white head from a 12 oz. bottle. It was a little disappointing for a Goose product, but I guess it was alright... I’d drink it again if I got the opportunity
Yellow with a small white head. Weak fruity citrus aroma. Sweet and malty flavour with American hops.
clear gold with a small white head.  light body.  crisp kolsch-like body.  easily drinkable.  grainy with hint of sweetness.

12 oz. bottle poured to my SA lager glass. A chilled hazy golden color with a modest white head that quickly diminished to a film and a foamy ring, but left some web-like, clingy lacing. The aroma was light Pils malt and a hint  of apple core. The flavor added soft malt and low hop bitterness. The carbonation was fizzy and the finish offered some dryness. A crisp, sessionable brew.
Surprisingly good beer.  Pale orange  with a foamy white head.  Hops, grain and fruit in the smell.  Nice crisp flavor.  I was pretty impressed with this one.  A nice summer brew.
Draft from east village tavern.  Kind of a boring kolsch, maybe it was the tap.

335ml bottle (K CM, Kamppi)

Pale orange, brief head. Pleasant light ale aroma, fruitier than I
expected from a kolsch, but definitely has that watered-down feel.
Sweet palate, soft carbonation. Weird taste, a bit like a watered-down
pale ale aromatics-wise, but with slightly lagery hints to the malty 
body. Quite biting stinging hopping, again not really an authentic
kolsch. There’s some swimming-pool water there too. Some paperiness
in the finish, a touch of pepper too. A curious mix. What I reckon
is that they took a 7%-ish pale ale, and mixed it with some cheap 2% 
low-alcohol pils. Voila - 4.5% "kolsch". Prove me wrong...

Yellow pour with a foamy, white head that fades to a nice lacing.  The aroma is light grains, pear, grape and yeast.  Crisp but fruity flavor with notes of bread, lemon, pear, white grape, and apple with a slight yeastiness to the finish.  Medium thin body with lots of carbonation.
Citrusy taste. Golden in color and has a white head. Good beer for a summer day with friends. Not a MUST buy.

Bottle  from traders joes poured golden and clear with white head aromas of pale grains,hops and fruits, taste is mild from pale malts , hops and citrus maybe great on a hot summerday but nothing to write home about

Bottled, alc. 4.7% (Beer Hunters’, BB 04/2010). 
Pale, slightly hazy yellow color, small white head. Aroma is soapy lemony with kind of unfermented sugar, wort note (although it is the most likely from yeast). Light palate, crisp mouthfeel, also a bit oily. Pale malty with light lemony hops. Refreshing, but just too boring and watery for being a good Kölsch. This is a bit like pale lagers of mainstream brewpubs. Could have more hops at least.

Bottled at Mallaskukko, Turku. Pale golden, thin disappearing white head. Mineral, slightly citric aroma with little soapiness and yeast. Flavor is minerals, clean malts, little citric fruits and kiwi, quite strong yeastiness, very mild hops and bubblegum in the finish. Not really crisp enough, a tad disturbing mineral notes in there too. Light bodied, strong foaming carbonation. Totally forgettable summerbrew.

(Bottle) Pale golden and clear. Small white head. Mild grassy aroma. Light bodied palate with medium carbonation. Lightly malts, grass, freshness, fruitiness, grain and ligjt bitterness in taste. Grain and light bitterness in aftertaste.

Golden color with a foamy but quickly dissipating head. Grainy aroma with a hint of citrus. Body is slightly dry and the flavor has hints of wheat, hops and grains. A pretty crisp and refreshing summer brew.
tap at brewery.  golden pour with white frothy yead.  wheat, grain, lemon aroma.  nice grainy body with fresh lemon.  light and refreshing.  I could drink this all day.

12 oz. bottle. Pours a thin short lived head, over a slightly cloudy, pale yellow (SRM 5) body......nose of light malts, hay, grass, slight hops.....taste is light malt, light hop, dry throughout....mouth feel is light, bubbly. A pleasant light beer that meets its style reasonably well.

355 ml bottle. Finland.
Pale golden colour with small white head.
Sweet fruity and grainy aroma. Fruit, malty, grainy and slightly corny flavour. Some bitterness in taste.

fruity sweet  apricot flavor in hops it is exactly the best way i have ever tasted it. tart and chalky it is fairly simple and pretty good. it finishes light with just a bit of lingering flavor. it has good carbonation. surprised it does’nt rate a bit higher.
Light sweet bready/grainy nose. A touch of hops. Pours light golden with a soft white head. The flavor is lightly sweet with notes of bread, grain, honey, a dash of corn maybe, and a crisp finish.

Pours a cloudy orange-straw color with foamy white head that diminishes quickly.  Aroma has notes of citrus, mainly orange; a bit flowery, clover.  Taste is wheat, coriander, earthy, medium hopped, surprisingly creamy texture.  Good Kolsch!

Pours a clear golden with a fluffy white head. Aroma is malty with hints of lemon and corn. Taste is very much the same: corn, malt, some lemon and other fruity notes, honey, and earthy hops. Mediocre for its style.

Pours a pale yellow with a small white head. The aroma is light and grassy... pils malt and mild hops. Flavor is nice and refreshing. A mix of grassy hops and light but sweet malt. Clean, crisp finish. Perfect for summer outings.

12oz bottle.

Pale gold with a nice puffy white cap, Aromas of grains grassiness and light apple tones.

Light malt in the front some apple and grass, light clean finish. Approachable quenching and tasty, great summer Kolsch

Bottle, Rehills, Newcastle. Great bittersweet pale ale. Juicy malt and fruity hops combime to give a truly refreshing summer ale. Sherbert and citrus flavours on the tongue, in particular, an orangey flavour, with a good lingering finish, that becomes pleasantly tangy towards the end.

pours a pale golden yellow, effervescent, with a thin white head.....aroma of grassy hop and light grain.... flavors of grassy hop and grainy malt. thin mouthfeel.  quite drinkable on a hot summer day but not all that great if given options.

Bottled 5/26, so about a month old. Pale yellow with an impressively rocky white head. Slight hop aroma. Light in body and surprisingly light in carbonation. Faint lemon taste with lagery hops (Saaz). Not much malt body. Finishes dry. Very drinkable; what it intends to be.
(bottle). Pours a clear golden color. Medium white head. Light malt aroma with light fruit. Very light malt flavor. Short duration. Soft carbonation. Thin texture. Fair lacing.

Clear pale golden in color with a frothy white head that leaves nice lacing.  Bubbles continually rising in the beer.  Appearance makes me think this will be a refreshing beer.  Sweet malty aroma, like sweet bread, is light.  Flavor is light as well, malts with a banana honey undertone.  Mildly watered down.  Somewhat medium bodied, coats the tongue nicely but leaves the mouth a little sticky.

12 oz bottle.  Clear straw brown with a perky white head.  Nose is dough, corn and faint lemon.  Foamy then kind of slick.  Taste is mild tangerine with a squirt of lime.  Dry finish with hints of sweetness.

From the bottle, nice bit of malt & slight lemon peel on the nose.  Palate nicely rounded, soft barley coming through that fades into dryness.  It’s the Ronseal of beers, a summer beer & that’s it, nothing fancy but would be very pleasant in the hot weather & thus a beer I shall not be revisiting much in England.

Thanks (I think) to rustychiles for the share on this. Aroma: corn, corn, corn, corn, corn (mild vomit?). Taste is quite bubbly with with some light pils and quite a bit of corn. The aftertaste is better than the beer itself. Somewhat like cornbread in a good way. Better than Bud, but not much. Looks cool.
Pale yellow hazy with a white head. Aroma is corn malt and grass. Flavor is malt, corn, grass and a a fruity sweetness. Mediocre but not in any way bad.
On tap at Wrigleyville Goose Island. Poured  gold with a white head. Aroma was of barley and malts. Flavor had some underlying sweet notes, but other than that, quite basic.

Pours cloudy pale yellow with a 3 finger fluffy white head that has good retention. Aroma is straw, sweet grass, hints of apricot, some bready yeast notes, citrus and a touch of lime soda. Flavor is sweet and somewhat sour citrus to start, fruity yeast esters in the middle, and some nice lemongrass and hay to finish. Palate is thin and fairly sweet all the way through with a slightly slick feel toward the back. Good stuff overall, I really can find much fault in it as a nice summertime quencher, it’s not the most interesting or complex... but that’s not what it’s here for. Light, thirst quenching, and delicious. I should probably add that I have had this stuff a number of times in the past and it has never tasted this good. I think it probably goes south pretty quickly.

12 oz bottle. Had this a few times, and it is a wonderful session beer that you can drink straight from the bottle, but for this tasting, I poured it into a glass. Pours a dark, yet pale yellow, with a small white head that dies quickly. Smells of VERY light hops, some malt, a little bit of fruit (reminds me of tangerine), and maybe some yeast. Tastes of that fruit taste, a little malt, a hint of hops, and thats about it. Very light, drinkable. Sessionable, I’m a lightweight and I could drink a 6 pk of this is in one sitting, but it is nice during the summer.

Draft at Harry Caray’s Tavern, Chicago.  Hazy light gold pour with thin white head.  Aroma fruity, yeasty.  Flavor of sweet malt and some citrus. Thin body and texture.  Would be refreshing on a hot summer day, which this was not.  Not bad.

Bottle.  Poursa hazy gold with a thin white head.  Aroma is sweet malts, a small bit of hops and not much else.  On the palate it is refreshing and crisp.  The flavor was a bit watered down, but it was refreshing for a hot day.  I am not a big fan of a Kolsch, but this one was pretty good.

Sampled at Chicago O’Hare at the Goose Island bar there. Pours out a hazy yellow with a white head that quickly goes away. Aroma is a touch of sweet malts and some fruit buried in there. Taste is very much the same, I dunno this one left me wanting more. Kolsch can be excellent for a nice fruity refresher but this one was just off for some reason. Not the best example of a Kolsch I’ve had, but then again, I haven’t had very many. Perhaps I’ll need to visit this one again.

A blonde Kolsch with a thin white head. A fruity aroma with light mineral notes, and a bit of boiled veggies. In mouth, a clean crisp malt with light sweet notes, and a bit of hops. Refreshing.  On tap at Clybourn, May 17 2009.

12 oz. bottle (2009) in a makeshift Kolsch glass; slightly hazy golden w/ an initially brimming white head that steadily devolved into some insipid bubbles; aroma is pretty empty, barring a slightly sweet maltiness; flavor is again nothing special, w/ some cereal and mild hops; quickly fades into a clean, dry finish; not as refreshing as they say and eminently forgettable.

Mild -sessionable - refreshing. 

Diminishing white head, spare lacing. Sunflower yellow clear brew. Nose is bread, a little metal, sweet. Average malt presence with hints of cereal and grain. Grassy, earthy light hops support. Light body, thin texture.


Not bad, but I doubt I’d ever purchase a six pack.

Pale gold with a thin white head.
Aroma is light sweet grainy malt and grassy/straw hop.
Earthy slightly sweet malt flavour, with a tangy grassy hop balance.

Bottle.  Pours a golden body with a thin white lacing.  Sweet citrus and wheat, cereal notes and a light bread y and spiced infusion.  Thin and dry. Not a bad summer brew but nothing to write home about.
Pours a cloudy golden color with a fluffy head. Pleasant aroma, light flavor with a little bite.  A nice drinkable summer beer.
Tap, bar, Chicago. Golden colour, white head. Aroma is grassy and earthy. Flavour of caramel malts, grassy hops. Slightly dry finish. Above average Kolsch.
Bottle.  Pours a yellow gold color with a white fluffy head.  Fruity and light aroma, and the taste follows.  A with a nice hoppy, wheat bite.  A medium bodied, light malt balance.
Poured cloudy yellow. Light fruity aroma. Light flavor with touches of malt and floral hops. Very subtle. Drinkable summer beer, but nothing stands out.

Bottled on 3/27/09.  Pours a Pilsner yellow with a small but compact white head. Aroma shows significant lemon and citrus, pilsner malt marmalade.  Yellow cake.  Flavor is clean, dry, and to the point.  Super clean with a dry, super quick finish.  This is fine, really, about what you’d expect.  Not bad if it’s what you’re in the mood for.
TAP: gold/yellow pour, citrus & light malt on the nose, on taste add to that a slight amount of hop character and carbonation. Not spectacular, but decent.
Tap at GI.  Yellow/gold pour.  Some light citrus hop, grain and malt.  Flavor is just ok.  clean and fresh with citrus, fair malt character and lively carbonation.
Bottle. Yellow and initially crisp but lacks flavour. First impressions are quite good but any taste and charater soon dissapear. Dissapointing and wouldn’t expect it to be a big seller in Cologne.

Bottle at the O’Hare venue. The only change here seems to be the seasonal bottle. Pale gold color, slightly hazy, with an ok white head. Light citrus aroma over pale malt. Medium minus body with mild carbonation. Flavor is light hop over light malt. More dry than not. Seems a kolsch.

Appearance:  moderately rich gold color for the style; mild haze; white head with above average persistence

Aroma:  overall, still quite muted; maybe light malt plus slight hop; does have mild fruit aroma; 

Flavor:  light fruity sweetness; low to medium-low bitterness; low hop presence; good spark from carbonation

Mouthfeel:  textbook; smooth and crisp; closer to medium body; high carbonation

Seriously, over 60 Goose Island ratings and I never rated the Summertime?  I remember really loving this beer when I first started drinking non garbage.  Pours gold with white head.  Just a little bit of hops to add some bitterness and citrus and a nice body.  Makes this beer really easy to drink in the summertime.  I prefer this over the 312.

Pours yellow color with a small white head. Nose of fruits, grainy, earthy hops. Inital taste is grainy like the aroma, touch of citrus, small balancing sweetness, some resin. Finishing with a average palate duration and decent hop balance. Refreshing and crisp.Average head retention. Good balancing carbonation.

On tap at Romans on GI Night. Aroma was a slight apple tinged German malt,all very soft as it should be,this style not known for a big fragrance, Taste mostly grainey with just a hint of tartness, and some noticeable bittering,little bite from the carbonation, pleasant as can be, probaly tastes better when its more like summer

Ours a shiny golden yellow with a thick creamy white head. Aroma is very nice fresh grain that doesn’t come across as stale or old. Nice bits of citric fruit and just a hint of spicy hops. Flavor starts with a burst of sweet citric fruit that is inviting and refreshing. Picks up some grain and bread notes before giving a spicy hop bite towards the finish that tickles the tongue through the swallow leaving a dry crisp finish. Medium body and active carbonation. Really resfresing for the kolsch style and perfect for the hot dog days of summer.
i prefer 312 to summertime.  this was ok.  light  golden , . not a bad bbq summertime beer.
Great fluffy head.  Nice lace finish.  Sour, grainy nose.  Powdery palate.  It does have a crisp kolsh flavor but very citrusy.  Leaves something to be disired.

Pours a clear light golden color with a nice fluffy white medium head. 
The aroma is very bright with some orange and some yeastiness. 
Flavors of citrus are certainly prevalent in this one with a big orange character and some nice dry graininess. This is remarkably fruity without being very sweet.
Nothing to blow me over but I can imagine I’ll be drinking a few more of these this summer.

Very refreshing beer with a very prominent head. Strong citrus smell is followed by a subtle yet satisfying citrus flavor on the palate. Light orange coloration when it is poured. Really is, as the name suggests, a great summer beer.
Bottle.  Light gold color. Medium sized head. Lemon, Honey and Wheat aromas.  Hoppy dry finish.  Decent Summer Beer.
Bottle. Sweet, fairly refreshing but with an odd soapy character. This was absolutely nothing special.
12 oz bottle at Stockholm Beer Festival 2008. Hazy yellow color. Sweetish, malty and honeyish aroma with some fruitiness and apricot. Tastes the same with low bitterness. Pleasant and easy drinking.
On Tap.  Semi cloudy, thin white head. Aroma: hops and slight fruitiness. Refreshing!

Slightly hazy golden coloured body with a super thin white head and a small amount of bubbles rising from the bottom. Aroma of slightly funky malt, cardboard, fresh german hops and a twang of lemon. Light-bodied; Tart astringent tastes up front with a slight hop flavour and a good fresh taste. Aftertaste finishes nicely for a seasonal in summer - no bitterness, just a light hoppy note and a slight citrus feel. Overall, a good summer kolsch - light and refreshing with no off-flavours. I sampled this twelve ounce bottle purchased at Dominick’s in Schaumburg, Illinois on 06-August-2005.

On tap at the brewpub. Pours golden with a small, foamy white head. Aroma is of honey, malt, spice, and wheat. Taste is very sharp, crisp malt with wheat, spice, citrus, and hops. Very mild beer, that is refreshing. Very drinkable. I could definitely get tanked on this one.

On tap at the brewpub. Pours a clearish yellow, with good white foam. Very classic german pils nose, bright, grassy, and puckery. Great cracker character. Bright, fresh drinkable, lightly ale yeast touched, lightly lemong sweet deliciousness. Nice tangy, bright pils malt finish. Awesome. Balanced, airy, drinkable and flavorful.

Pours to a light golden color with thin white head that dissipates quickly and leaves little lacing. Aroma of honey, wheat and lemon, with a tingly, biting mouthfeel. Flavor is more of the honey, wheat and lemon found in the nose, with a hoopy bitter-dry finish.

Had this in the dead of winter, but can see how it would be a summertime favorite.
Bottle. Pours a yellow color with a thin white head. Smells of citrus and spice. Taste is malt and sweet. Very crisp and clean. Easy to drink.

Found a bottle recently.  Pours a very clear golden with a wispy white head.  The aroma has a spicy hops scent with some sweet pils malt as well.  First flavor is the spicy hops flavor which subsides into the sweet pils tones ending with a sweet, crisp lemon citrus ending.  Overall one of the better Kolschs I have had.

Tried this on a windy fall day in Chicago - it actually snowed during the afternoon - so for a self-entitled ""summertime"" beer, the circumstances of the tasting are not really fair. Did not leave a great impression - but ncie fruitiness and some malts - I imagine it would work really well on a warm day.

Tap at the Clybourn location. Very pale. Crisp body, decent hops, biscuity malts, and a touch of sweetness. They called this a kolsch, which for once actually seems like an accurate descriptor of an American beer.
Bottle:  medium golden with some light sweet fruit aromas.  Taste is smooth with more light fruit and light malt.  Pretty decent.

(10/9/08) Draught sample at the brewpub in Clybourn, Chicago. Clear golden. Aroma is rather hoppy, with some flowers, some bready malt and nice fruitiness. Sweetish bready flavor with some fruits, finishes dry with moderate hoppiness. Medium-bodied.

Objectively speaking:
Fresh on tap at Clybroun, this was an absolutely superb Kölsch, better than most I’ve had in Cologne.


I like:
Absolutely spot on. This is one pint I downed in less than 10 minutes and could have done it again until I fell as natural as it felt. Precisely what I’m looking for in the style. Hugely refreshing, focused, crisp soft cerealic taste, based on doughy freshness. Lasting lacy white head. Gentle creamy, minimal acidity acts as a bonus. Not bubbly, but enthusiast, rather big-bubbled, coating carbonation. Soft noble hop kiss in the finish leaves lots of room for the breadiness and graininess. Fresh! Fresh! Fresh!


I dislike:
I can’t believe how low this is scored. The bottles must not translate the exuberant freshness all that well.
(Bottle 35,5 cl) Clear golden with a white head. Sweetish malty nose. Medium body with sweet malts and basically no hoppiness. Drinkable but bland. 190908

Bottle: Poured a golden color Kolsch with an average pure white foamy head with minimal retention and no lacing. Aroma consists of some semi-sweet malt with not much else to report. Taste is a mix between some semi-sweet malt without the grainy aspect and no distinctive feature form the yeast which is usually the case with this style. Average at best and not something I would like to try again.

Bottle. A Kolsch eh? Thought this was a little bland and lacking anything that would make me drink this again given any choice. Pale yellow gold (like a lucky lucky man’s bracelet) with a thin white head. A little watery and metallic. Didn’t care for it much, but didn’t hate it. Cheers.
Pours golden yellow with a slight haze.  Smell is grains, citrus.  Taste is slightly sweet caramel with bitterness in the fihish.  Crisp and refreshing.  Nice Kolsch.
On tap. Pours a hazy golden color with white head. Aroma of lemon, cerial grains and light hops. Taste is mild and semi sweet.  Very one dimensional but easy to drink.

12-oz bottle received via trade with unclemike.  Pours clear and sparkling dark yellow with a spare, fizzy, white head, mostly diminishing with spare lacing.  Aroma is heavy malt (hay, straw, meal), light hops (flowers, grass), average yeast (dough, sweat) with notes of grape and cooked cabbage.  Light bodied, sticky texture, average carbonation, and a chalky finish.  Average duration, light sweetness, acidity, and bitterness.

From bottle.  August Dayton Beer Tasting event - Favorite Summer Brews.  

Pours clear gold with decent head. Light bodied.  Not a lot of aroma or flavors to grab  onto.  Decent lawnmower beer but not up to par with some of their other beers.
Bottle at GBBF08. Weak fruity aroma. Clear shiny golden colour. Small white head. The flavour has a little caramel but is quite light. A little rough bitterness in the finish.

Pours a very light gold that is murky and pale in color.  Typical.  Decent head on the pour.  Smell is slight fruit, mostly lemon.  All malt in the taste.  Good amount of bitterness.  Very crisp, light and refreshing.  Not my cup of tea, but good enough.

A Mes rate: bottle at GBBF.
Pale gold with a thin white head. Dull and watery with very little action. Faint fruity notes, some card and metal and hints of butter. Bland as hell, very short in the finish, pretty lifeless all round.

Bottled at Monk’s Café, Stockholm.  Lightly hazy pale golden, small head. Almost neutral nose. Fairly light bodied dense and somewhat sweet. Fruity with some cereals. The short fruit flavour quickly fades out into slight metal. More bland/fruity than refreshing.

Kolsch has long been one of my favorite beer styles, so it’s no wonder that I can’t wait for those hot summer days, when nothing but a clean, crisp and gentle kolsch could possibly be better.  Goose Island actually makes an excellent example of this style.  It pours a very pale gold, with a brilliant, lustery, whipped topping-like head, and leaves plenty of foam and lacing.  The aroma is like fresh hay, a warm summer evening, and a cool breeze.  It has a sherbety, ripe red strawberry, herbal lavendar calmness.  Summertime’s taste is ever-so-gentle- tickling the tongue, bringing forth lemon sorbet, bubblegum, strawberries, and a fresh, minty, cooling zestiness that quenches the thirst and soothes the soul.

Draft at Goose Island Clybourn brewpub, listed simply as "Kolsch".  A clear very pale straw, little head or carbonation.  No noticeable aroma.  Things pick up with the flavour.  First taste has significant flavour and body to it.  Grassy malts and crisp hops seem like they fit the style, though I’m certainly no expert.

bottle - Pours clear gold with a light, slightly fruity malt aroma.  The flavor is of light biscuity malt, a touch of fruit, and some mild hops.  It’s light bodied, smooth and refreshing.  There’s not a lot here to get excited about, but it it was it is, a nice, decent summer brew.
Bottled - GBBF 2008.  Gosh this was boring.  A very clear golden colour with buttery malts in the nose, which became a bit sickly.  The same in the mouth; more sickliness.  Not much fun.
Bottle @ GBBF 08. Clear yellow color, short head. Grassy aroma, bit sweet. Typical kolsch indeed.

Pours a semi cloudy golden pale with a small fim white head. Aroma is lightly sweet lemon, grass and various light summer fruits. Flavor is very fruity but does have a nice malty backbone along with light hay and earthy hops. Finishes somewhat short and light spicy. Light to medium bodied, crisp texture. Probably the best American Kolsch I have ever consumed.
Bottled@GBBF2008. Yellow colour, small white head. Aroma is hops, fruits and mild cellary notes Quite hayish flavour with some saltwater and sweet fruity notes.
Clear golden with medium white head. Sweet malty aroma with caramel notes. Sweet fruity flavor with malty and caramel notes. Ends sweet.

I give this beer credit for seeming Kolsch-like, as I understand the style from previous experiences with the style.  It is very crisp with a metallic flavor I’ve tasted in other Kolsch’s.  Not bad, but this wouldn’t be my first choice of beer to have on a hot day.  However, I do give Goose Island credit for making a summer seasonal that is a genuine beer style, and resisting the temptation to make a summer beer that is fruity, citrus-y, and too sweet.

Appearance is a clear pale yellow, that is translucent.  Aroma is faint.  Flavor is crisp and metallic.  Mouthfeel is clean, dry and crisp.

Like I said, I’d weakly recommend this.  Not bad.

Great summertime beer. I’ve tried pretty much all of the other "summeetime" beers put out by brewers and this is one of my favorites. Great for a hot summer day. Citrus, lemon taste, and a nice golden yellow color. Not too thick of a head but just enough to get the job done. Slightly over priced in my opinion. Paid $7.99 for a 6 pack on sale. Should be more like $6.99 at the most.

12 oz bottle. Pretty good pour, medium bubbly white head, good staying power for it being so bubbly, nice lacing, golden straw yellow, ton of carbonation.  Light aroma, mostly light yeast and lemon, dinner rolls.  Not as fizzy tasting as it looks (a good thing), light bodied, but fairly hoppy, some citrus, grassy, slightly evident pale malt, crisp dry finish.  Alright, did the trick on the 4th of july though.
nice and crisp, clean, lemony flavor with nice long finish, one of the better domestic summer-styles imho, great for hot/humid illinios summers. outstanding
Bottle from Tuckers Maltings. Light, slighlty fruity, smooth, easy on the palate. Just a wonderful beer
Not awesome, but much better than expected.  Very true, it would taste great on a hot summer day, but that’s why air conditioning was invented and I can drink whatever I want despite the season.

Bottle. This is a very refreshing Kolsch-style brew. Perfect balance of malt with a dash of hops. Almost reminiscent of a wheat beer, except with more flavor. Would definitely recommend on a hot summer day.
12oz bottle, bottled on 05/21/08. Poured a medium and lighlty hazy golden color with an averaged sized white head. Aromsa of grains, wheat, and some citrus. Tastes follow suit. Thinner body.

Bottle.  Goodbar Beer Club.  Yellowy gold, white head.  Nose is dougy malts, light lemon.  Simple but nice. Flavor is lemon, doughy malt, undefined fruits.  A hint of richer malt in the finish.  Very good.
After a hot day mowing this is a great beer.  Very light with a small head.  Wheat aroma and taste with a slight bitter hop finish.

Bottle.  Excellent summer time brew.  A nice German lager with a typical lager aroma characteristic.  Clear golden in color with a white head. Flavor is lightly hoppy and fruity, but mostly lagerish.  Similar to some pilsners, but with a more crisp and refreshing finish.  Mild overall.

Bottle thanks to bigmmartin.  Nice bread yeast aroma with some slight pine.  Flavor is slightly bland but mostly sweet with some very mild bitterness.  Mild carbonation as well.  Smooth and drinkable but not mind blowing.

It’s supposed to be a summer beer...which I suppose means light on the palate....a real thirst quencher....and I suppose it works....because it basically tastes like water.  There’s not much beer here.  The aroma is non-existent, there isn’t any spice or bite in the flavor.  It’s not bad, but its not good.  It’s basically a slightly better version of a ’Silver Bullet’....which doesn’t work since its so much more expensive, and its not worth it.  Avoid this, and get the cheap beer for the summer thirst quencher.

12 oz. bottle.  Pours a cloudy gold with a thin creamy white head that lasted until mid-glass and left very light lace.  After several minutes, the beer becomes a yellow gold and is nearly clear.  Light, pleasant aroma of malt and lemon.  The flavor is very similar with malt and lemon.  Crisp and refreshing with barely any bitterness at the finish.  A very solid Kolsch.

Bottle. Pours a pale gold with a small, bright white head. Light aroma, of hops, malt, and citrus. Yeast and malt taste, sweet and bitter, with notes of lemon. Lingering lemony bitterness. Tasty and drinkable.

12 oz bottle, pours clear golden color with big frothy white head.  Light aroma of wheat, slightly fruity, and floral.  Taste is malty and wheat, very crisp and light mouthfeel.  Very refreshing, a nice summer beer!

(Bottle, Monk’s Café, Stockholm, 1 July 2008) Yellow colour with frothy, white head. Fruity nose with notes of lemon, peaches and grassy, floral hops. Fruity taste with tropical fruit, pineapple and hay. Fairly sweet, but well balanced kölsch. Nice and summery but hardly ground breaking.
Eh.  It’s got it’s place I suppose, but it’s fairly disappointing.  A bit of sweet maltiness, but a cardboard finish.  Drinkable but certainly not to search for.

This Northern German style beer pours a hazy pale gold with a light white head, mostly dissapating. The aroma is citrus and spice. Very creamy and velvety smooth on the palate. Taste is light, with a whisper of grapefruit and lemon. Finishes with a bit of dry hoppiness. Very refreshing summer beer best enjoyed after a game of croquet, lawn bowling or badminton.

A slight fruity aroma, it pours a somewhat hazy light yellow, with a thin white head.  A bit of sweetness starts out the flavor, which is quickly stopped by a touch of grassy hops.  Nice and thirst quenching.  Not spectacular, but very drinkable.

Not really going to complain on this one.  It has its place, but its not something that should be sought out.  Better than your average lager, its got some grassiness in there.  I am seeing this around alot, which is a good sign of things to come i think.

Pours golden yellow with a frothy white head. Smells like grains and yeast, perhaps some mild fruits.Flavor is very refreshing. slightly sweet with fruitiness, and yeastiness also pops its glob on your tongue.

Cloudy champagne color with a white head. A very light hop aroma with touches of grass and citrus.  Very light and refreshing taste, faint malt flavor, nice lemon citrus finish. Crisp, light and refreshing beer

Bottle.  Pours a light yellow with a white head with a lot of carbonation.  Aroma of light fruits, lemon, lager yeast.  Flavor of light fruits, wheat, spices.  Very light, fruity, and refreshing.  Enjoyable beer.

Very light golden, little to no head. Light grass and a touch of citrus sourness. Dry at the front getting towards lemon, not all that sour though, just reminiscent of lemon. Spritzy and dry with a somewhat roasty hop presence. Might not be the freshest sample, but I think there should be more flavors noticeable than what were.
Bottle.  Golden beer with a light head.  The aroma is fruity, malty and lightly dry.  The flavour is fruity, hopped and mildly dry.  Overall a very nice beer.

12 oz bottle: Pours like a pale yellow wit with a soft white head that fades.  The nose is beery with soft peach and apple esthers.  Spritzy carbonation is appropriate for the nice, drying body.  Subtle notes of caramel and honey blend with a moderate dose of grassy German hops.  Finishes dry and champagne like, with a soft punch of pear.  Very refreshing on this hot, hot day.

Bottle. Aroma almost champagne-like with light fruits abound, a sweetish (for lemon), gourmet candy-like lemon, pale/wheaty malts, just enough hops to sense them, and surprisingly a pleasant, carressing touch of alcohol. Flavor continues along the same lines, bittering hops come out more in a supporting role, but a very strong supporting role. Again, nice light fruit presence. Obviously very drinkable, and so very, very tasty. 3.13...bah!
pours bright straw yellow with medium white head.  aroma is malty/estery.  very clean flavor.  great lawnmower beer.

Tasted 5/19/08.  12oz bottle.  Filtered with a golden hue.  White rim of head.  Toasty grainy nose.  Light to medium bodied with grainy mild light malts.  Slightly bitter hops.  Fruity esters.  Berries and candy lemon.  Tart and grainy.  Mildly sticky.  Solid Kolsch!
Crisp and clean.... clear orange poor not much head and no lacing... refreshing but not my favorite.

Suprisingly wheaty for a Kolsch, or maybe it was just me. Pours a slightly cloudy golden borderline orangeish colour with a full rising white head. Lemon, grass and yeast on the nose. Taste is smooth, fruity with a semi tart finish.
your average session beer. Average summer style kolsch. I could drink 10 of these on a warm day. Heavy carbonation, roasted malt, citrus.

12 oz. bottle from John’s Grocery (Iowa City, IA). Pours a hazy yet bright yellow with a lot of visible carbonation and fairly decent white head. Aromas of light hops, grass, and a touch of sweetness. Initial taste is a smooth lighter maltiness with a bit of spicy sweet hop notes. Dry finish after the sweet and hops are gone through, this was a surprising rate indeed. The fresher the better, as I’ve had this brew when it wasn’t this good. Still, a wonderful summer session beer. Yum.
Stinks like hell. Nice bright yellow hue and a quickly falling head. I didn’t know you were supposed to drink it from a stange or stUrzen. Learn sumpen new every day.
Draft @ Clyborne. Light in color with a small head. Crisp, clean with a mellow maltiness and just the right twinge of lemon.

Bottle, bought @ The Rake, London.
Pours lightly hazy yellow-golden with a small creamy white head. Aroma is softly hoppy, light citrc. High carbonation. Subdued crispy malts in the flavour, biscuits, subdued hops. Wonderful balance and even better freshness.

In bottle at Jerry’s. Straw-gold with big, foamy, white head / Light lemon and wheat nose / Light bodied, crisp, with fine carbonation and tart, dry finish / Flavors of lemon and wheat / A textbook example of the style?
Pour is clear golden yellow with a thin white head...smell is lightly grassy and toasty...taset is sweet and malty with some chewy grain flavors...nice...
12 oz bottle pours golden with a medium off white head.  Aroma of grassy hops and soapy lemon.  Flavor is lemony with a strange aftertaste.
poured gold with a thin white head.  Not much going on in the aroma or flavor.  Grain, corn, citrus...that’s about it.  Not good
12oz bottle. Now I know I’m not the only one that though it had a soapy aftertaste. A little too lemony, and also weak on carbonation. I just didn’t like this one.

Bottle. Pale golden color, thin white head, some lacing. Lemon and grass in the aroma, the flavor is citrusy and sweet with a great dry finish. The mouthfeel is maybe a tad thin, but not for a summer beer, and well-carbonated, refreshing. Overall, I’d say this beer tastes like summer, if that makes sense, and would be great on a hot summer day. By all means, a great session beer while watching a baseball game or grilling.
Bottle.  some fruit flavors.  not a very good aftertaste.  golden color with small white head.

Bottle poured light golden, with thin white head. Some citrus fruit and vague hopiness in the aroma. Flavour not too awful but aftertaste dishwateresque.  Expected a lot better. Insipid and very disappointing. Would not try again during any season.

Bottled, 355ml, from Westholme Stores, Goring on Thames, Oxon. Yellow gold with slight head. How dissapointing is this? Meek, malty and largely flavour free, now I know that Kolsch’s are hardly the most flavour full beers but this doesn’t even touch most Kolsch’s. Some lemon / vanilla, verging on the level of poor. Oh Dear.

Bottle. Alc. 4.7%. Clear medium yellow color with a average to large, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, white head. Aroma is moderate malty, grain, wheat, fruity, light hoppy, lemon. Flavor is moderate sweet, light light acidic and light to moderate bitter with a average duration, and a dry finish. Body is light to medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. (270108)

Bottle.  Golden with a small head and a decent sparkle.  Aromas are clean, fresh and floral with biscuit malts.  Hints of citrus and soap.  Flavours are floral and citrus with herbal notes.  Some addictive saltiness.  Dry on the finish.  Fresh as a Summer day.
Bottle at home ... typical lager hop aroma ... grass hop ... quite sweet unusually so ... clean finnish with a little lager hop linger.
dough, grass, golden, hazy, aminimal head, soft carbonation, oily feel, "good for a lager".
Bottled from utobeer. Aroma is cornish with grainy malt and grassy candy sugar hints. Taste is more balanced, grainy cornish, grassy bitter but alround a balanced session beer.

This is a nice summer beer, and actually has a little more complexity that typical kolsch styles.  It is semi sweet, semi dry, and has a nice fruity ester flavor that melds well with the quick dry clean crisp finish.  Balance is about as good as it gets for a kolsch

Draught at the brewpub, Wrigleyville location
Hazy light blond color, creamy head. The aroma has some cereals and malt. The mouthfeel is weak, with some residual sweetness, but not enough flavor or bitterness. Too simple.

Enticing snout of cork, wood, bananas and ice cream. A bit too fruity to be totally authentic. But the softly malty character is, minus the spritz. Torrential bead fizzing out quickly. Slight oak and citrus. Ends up tasting too much like a cheap tinned Pils.

Bottle. Pours a hazy pale yellow color with a longlasting white head. Malty bready aroma with some grassy hints. Sweet malty bready and fruity flavor with some grassy hints. Fruity malty finish with some hoppy bitterness in the aftertaste.
Bottle. Poured a very light golden color. Aroma is stinky feet. Taste is watery but could be a good beer for a real hot day.
Great beer for the summer. Nice clean finish. Golden in color. Drink it in the shade on a hot day.
10-26-07 bottle. Cloudy golden color. Yeasty smell.  Very decent kolsch! Drinkable - but just isn’t my favorite style.

This beer is a beautiful golden honey color with almost no head.  Flavor is a super balance of malt and hop.  Honey and earthyness are prominent.  Tartness sits on the tip of the tongue.  It is a crisp and refreshing beer.  Perhaps the best Kolsch I have sampled.

Thanks to Gregis for the bonused bottle from my want list.
Gold with medium white head.  Smell typical sweet grassy malt smell of a kolsch with a light almost chemically character about it.  Taste is sweet up front, followed by a tart finish.  Very drinkable, simple, but decent summer beer.  Somewhat thin.
Bottle. Clear light gold. A clean Kolsch with a very light hop profile, some maltiness, but not sweet, a clean dry finish. Easy to drink, quenchable and refreshing, but not complex or remarkable.

On my old rating scale this comes through with a 3.4 maybe even 3.5 but with the new and maybe improved maybe not scaling system it scores a still sweet 3.3.   Drank this on a hot afternoon waiting for my butter covered filet to finish cooking.  Lite fruit flavors mixed with a bit of honey a hint of malt.  Refreshing to say the least. Pretty good.
Bottle. Clear gold colour with a moderate white head. Aroma of apricots, grass and a bit of pepper. The flavour was slightly sweet to start with, followed by a decent hop finish. Ok.
Bottle. Nice clean & crisp Kolsch. Nice summer beer on the deck. Nothing phenominal but decent
Bottle from Bottles York. So-so lager. Dry malt with a hint of peachy pineapple fruit and light grassy hop.

got in a goose island variety pack.  pours a clear gold, light head.  unique aroma, not strong, but subtle sour  dough.  taste was also fairly unique with a blend of lemon and honey.  very interesting, worth having a little warmer so the subtle notes come out.

Poured from a 12oz bottle into a shaker.  This beer poured a hazy, golden color with no head.  The aroma was made up of lemon, orange, grass, and also some light spiciness.  The flavor consisted of grass/hay, light lemony citrus notes, sweet malts, and also some noble hops.  The mouthfeel was light-bodied with a good amount of carbonation.  Overall, this was a decent beer.  Good for easy drinking on a hot day.

Date: 09/08/2002

Mode: Bottle

Source: Trade



Clear yellow, sweet malty aroma with a hint of floral hops, light malt flavor, hint of bitterness, well made



Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 5/10; Flavor: 5/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 10/20

Rating: 2.7/5.0
Score: **/4

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

The score was calculated based upon the notes and an old scoring system.

Bottle. Light gold, with a quickly fading white head.  Sour malt aroma, without much of a hop note.  Stale malt aroma, almost a raw grain flavor as well.  Heavier that I expected for a beer labeled summertime.
Bottle- tiny head, somewhat hazy, a caramel-honey aroma. An exeptionally sweet initial flavour with a sticky honey finish. Very enjoyable, I would love to try it on tap.
ON tap at Clybourn; flavor was of grain and funk.  Not very good; flavor was much of the same.  Pretty disappointing.  Only good thing was decent hop finish.

12oz bottle wifr bought in Wi. A toated grain aroma with some citrus. Gold body with white head. The zesty lemon flavor made this beer for me. Otherwise could a been just another ordinary beer like the big 3 make.

Pours a sparkling gold with a white, frothy and lasting head that leaves decent lacing upon the glass. The nose is grainy, sour citrus, with a lightly yeasty backing. Light to medium-bodied and slick, it finishes slightly astringent. Sweet, lightly bready malt and mildly sour citrus. Crisp and refreshing. A nice summer beer and the best Kölsch that I’ve tried this summer.
bottle.  Pours light golden/yellow with a smalll white head.  Light lemon grass aroma.  Lemon and a bit of citrus in the taste.  Not bad.
Hint of lemon aroma.  Rather sweet clean grain flavor.  Not terribly complicated but quite refreshing and very easy drinking.
Gold colour. Sweet grainy aroma. Taste is slightly citric with a sweet malt background. Does what it says on the bottle.
Bottle at The Rake at London Bridge (London), poured a bright gold. A clean palate, very dry. A spritzy citrus flavour with grapefruit notes.

From the bottle. This beer pours a goldish straw yellow with a thin white head. Aroma is mild with hints of lemon grass and mild hops. the flavor is a bit tart and fruity with the lemon coming thru strong. Overall a very good kolsch good for hot summer days.

You’d be hard pressed to find a better BBQ beer than this gem, straight from the heart of Chicago. The Goose explores the often neglected Kolsch style and hits the target dead on. Light, malty, with a nice tartness in the finish, clean clear golden appearance and light to medium carbonation. Hop character is grassy and subdued with a slightly zesty lemon finish.
From a bottle at Old Chicago.  Summer beer tour.  Nice, crisp and refreshing with some lemon taste, enjoyable but not remarkable.

Well made kolsch, with a crisp tight taste and nice smooth palate.  This won’t make you remember it much beyond the smile of the first taste of a cold beer.  Well, first since the last one, of course.
great summer bear. very refreshing would be great for a summer bbq great with beef.  not a huge flavor but refreshing.

Extremely refreshing.  Nice and light with very pleasant carbonation.  Sweet malt very nicely balanced with the hops.  I actually went through this one so fast that it’s tough to remember much of anything specific.  Would definitely be willing to give a proper tasting to later on when I’m not so thirsty.

Pours a hazy straw, minimal white head.  Caramelly, slightly smoky aroma, a bit of green apple.  Flavor starts dry and astringent and very sour.  Finishes sort of malty and lagery.  Medium-thin body and with good complementing fizzyness.
This beer is very light and drinkable.  The taste leaves a little to be desired, but I suppose Kolsch is a pretty mild style.  I would buy again, especially on a hot day.

Tap at Old Chicago, Old Town, Wichita.  WTF is this?  It smells and tastes like modeling clay (for the latter, add a bit of sugar substitute in there as well).  It looks okay-- average yellow-- but smells and tastes like friggin’ modeling clay!
On tap @ the brewpub. Golden coloured with a medium sized head. Nice and crisp with notes of metal, bread and grass.

Nice pale yellow pour, with a smaller white head.  The head dissipates fast.  Aroma is slight hop, with some lemon grass notes.  Body is on the light side of medium.  Not at all watery, rather very crisp and clean.  the lemon grass comes out in the nose of the flavor.  The finish is fast and clean.  The carbonation is not over powering.  This is good beer.  I didn’t have high hopes....I was pleasantly surprised.

Kolsch might be one of my favorite type of lagers.  Pale yellow pour with medium sudsy white head.   Aroma of grass.   Flavor is very light like a dry cider.  Finish is slight hops & some bitter.  Body is crisp which compliments the flavor so I gave that a 4.  One of the better summer attempts I’ve had this year...
Had a slight fruity/lemon taste, enjoyed it before dinner.  Was smooth and plesant.
bottle.  pale ale with some fruity notes and a hopped up taste.  At first I was somewhat impressed but as it warmed up I was turned off.  Some yeast flavor mixed with lager flavor.

355ml bottle from Utobeer.  Pale clear gold, lasting white head.  Slight herby lemon aroma.  Very much a light lemon curdy aroma.  Smooth in mouth.  Light and drinkable.  Just as a Kolsch should be.. Lemon hop on end is very pleasant.  I like it.

Pours a golden color with a white head.  Aroma is of slight citrus, yeast, floral hops, light toastiness, and sweet malts.  Flavor is of citrus, lemon, and yeast up front that give way to a slight toastiness and grains on the finish.  A little watery.  Overall this really isn’t that great.

7/2/07  12 oz thanks to my future? aunts who through us a wedding shower.  Not my favorite goose island, but an excellent attempt to get something I might like none the less.  Pours a cloudy orange yellow thin head.  Nose is lightly malty, floral, and citrussy.  Flavors are similar, a little more citrus coming through.  I liked this more than I remembered from last year.  6/3/6/3/11 = 2.9


12oz bottle thanks to AJ for bringing this.  The same malty citrus and creamy notes of before but they come together nicer.  Creamy smooth body.  Easy to drink and enjoyable to throw back in the warm weather. 6/3/6/3/13 = 3.1
12oz, pours cloudy yellow. nose has bread, cereal, and wet grains. flavor is bready, slightly toasted, with mild citrus.  a nice refreshing summer beer.

6/20/2007:  Goose Island Summertime has a hazy (more like cloudy,actually) yellow color.  The aroma is bready with some palt malts and cereal.  The flavor is light with some toasty/bready malt and citrus hops.  There is a hint of bitterness in the finish.  The body is medium-light and feels thin on the palate.  Good, but not as good as I had expected.  Goose Island used to be one of my favorite regional micros, but I really think that their beers have slipped over there years and aren’t nearly as good as they once were.  It’s sad, but true an disappointing.



12 oz bottles shared by BeerBob at the Junedale Beer Klub June "Ales of Summer" beer tasting.  Thanks BB!

Pale golden color without a head.  Very light grass/corn aroma with a touch of malt.  The flavor is light yet satisfying, with sweet malty corn, grass, and a touch of hops.  A bit more hops would have been nice.  Very refreshing and tasted much as expected...
Another good summer beer. Good flavor and goes down smooth. Not the typical hoppy flavor I’m used to with Goose, but still good.

thought I was going to enjoy this after the first swallow but but the time I was finished with it I had a strong urge to brush my teeth, not sure if it was the beer or the paint fumes or something I ate, i’ll have to try again
Pours pale yellow with thin head.  Light aroma of grass, citrus, very light malts.  Flavor is mild and somewhat dry.  Could be better.
Chicago trip. Monday 14:17. On tap at Clybourn. Pale yellow. Thin white head. Hint of grassy hops. Hoppy clean beer. Delicate. A bit chewy in the finish.

(Tap) Pours a yellow color with a pretty tiny white head. Aroma is light. Taste is also relatively mild, and includes light malts and citrus. Dry and refreshing finish. Could stand to have a little more body to it. Maybe it’s the style, but this beer doesn’t seem to be on par with a lot of their other offerings.

Rated 8/5/06:  Pours a light gold color with a smooth head and good carbonation, there’s a nice clean sparkle to the appearance. Aroma is real faint and neutral. Crisp and refreshing on the palate coupled with a nice easy flavor. Light malty flavor that is somewhat dry with a tinge of citrus. Real smooth drink here simple and refreshing.
